Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analyzing and Exploiting Meta-information for Keyword Search on Semi-structured Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to provide high-quality keyword search results on semi-structured data in XML format. To address the challenge of handling inherent ambiguity in keyword search, fundamental techniques and an effective search engine are developed that exploit the meta-information in the data in order to infer user search intention and to achieve high search quality. The project includes novel research on the following key areas: (1) Query Result Generation: identifying relevant nodes in XML data and composing atomic and intact query results, each of which represents an object of the inferred user search goal; (2) Query Result Presentation: developing techniques for result ranking, snippet generation, and result clustering, in order to help users quickly find the most relevant results; (3) Advanced Queries and Data Models: supporting expressive search options and handling XML data with rich constraints; and (4) Efficiency: developing techniques for performance optimization, including indexes, materialized views, and top-k query processing. Furthermore, an axiomatic evaluation framework is initiated for formally reasoning about XML keyword search strategies.

The success of the project will advance the state-of-the-art of keyword search on XML data, enhance the research and education infrastructure in this area, and have broader impacts on both general public as well as scientific communities for information discovery. This research is intergrated with education through curriculum enhancement, student advising, workshops as well as outreach programs. Publications, software and course materials that are resulted from this project will be disseminated via the project website (http://web.njit.edu/~ychen/xseek.htm).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have developed a wide range of fundamental technologies for enabling users to use keyword queries to easily access semi-structured data and to retrieve highly relevant results by leveraging the rich meta-information embedded in semi-structured data. We have successfully completed the project and achieved the following outcomes. (i) We initiated a principled way of defining query results and of evaluating search quality of a keyword search engine using formal reasoning.  (ii) We proposed a novel query result definition that is driven by inferring user search intentions.  (iii) Due to the ambiguity of a keyword query and exploratory nature of a search, a search engine may not be able to deliver perfect results.  To address this, we developed a set of tools to help users navigate and analyze the returned results to quickly find the most relevant ones, such as result snippet generation, result comparison, result clustering, and result ranking. We also developed tools to assist users to issue queries by suggesting query refinement. (iv) To better understand users’ preference, we have developed effective techniques of analyzing user behaviors from a log and predicting user interests.  (v) Besides search quality improvement, we have also developed a suite of techniques for enhancing efficiency and scalability of keyword query processing, including designing indexes, answering queries using materialized views, and leveraging parallel processing framework. (vi) In addition to developing techniques to address the above challenges of processing keyword queries on tree-structured and graph-structured data in general, we have adapted and extended the techniques for processing a wide spectrum of semi-structured data, including workflows, text-rich semi-structured data such as online forums, data with incomplete or dirty information, data with varying degree of trustworthy levels, as well as archived data with temporal information. The results have been disseminated in over 30 research papers and three tutorials at premier conferences and journals. The PI has also organized a journal special issue and three workshops on this topic.

The outcomes of the project advance the state-of-the-art of processing keyword queries on semi-structured data. We not only developed novel solutions to challenging problems, but identified many emergent problems that call for further investigation by the community and open new research directions. The project cuts across and contributes to the disciplines of databases, information retrieval, data mining, and human-computer interaction. Since many research problems are defined based on challenges arise in real-applications, the outcomes have broader impacts on general public for information discovery, and impact to the fields of healthcare, scientific data management, finance and supply chain management.  The research is highly integrated with education. During the course of the project, the PI has actively involved doctoral, master and undergraduate students, and reached out to students from under-represented groups and high-school students. Three PhD dissertations and one Master thesis were resulted from the project. The outcomes also contributed to the institution on curriculum development as well as an establishment of a new PhD program.
